Terrestrial. The slalk-like attachment on the underside is interesting. I wonder if it’s part of the mushroom or a piece of debris that got attached?

Reminds me of Pholiota lenta.

results.notes: A small loose cluster fruiting under Eastern White Pine in suburban residential area. Largest cap: 7 cm, sticky; pore surface pale yellow at first with milky-colored droplets of liquid, narrow sterile margin on pore surface. Stem: 4 cm X 1.5 cm., tapering toward base, copious white mycelium, tiny almost concolorous glandular dots which darken when handled. Ammonia gray on flesh. KOH on flesh flashed pink then instantly turned gray. Did not get any chemical reactions on cap. Obtained cinnamon-brown spore print. I believe this mushroom was formerly known as S. lactifluus, a most descriptive name.
results.location_name: West St. Louis Co., Missouri, USA

results.notes: A small troop fruiting in a pile of mixed leaf litter and woody debris next to a very rotted fallen log in mixed woods, mostly Oak and Hickory. This observation was noted on a foray with friends (see additional posting # 238673) but none of us could identify it immediately. Caps whitsh/cream/pale yellow with yellowish umbo and wrinkled with some cross-veining. Gills appeared to have been lighter at one point but now colored brown with spores. Also appeared separated from stipe (perhaps since these were older specimens), but evidence of some attachment can be seen in the thumbnail image. Interesting and persistent skirt ring. Copious mycelium/rhizomes at base of stipe. Odor mild, somewhat fragrant. KOH on cap a slightly greenish gray (see last image). Obtained a chocolate-brown spore print, not reddish at all. Unfortunately, I inadvertently pitched the specimen dimensions which were written on the paper plate when I checked the spore print and found the cap et al had become a “maggot fest.”
results.location_name: Bootlegger's Run Trail, Creve Coeur Lake Memorial Park, Maryland Heights, Missouri, USA

results.notes:
> A gregarious group of 15-17 fruiting bodies (one cluster of 5 fbs with overlapping caps!) growing in moss under pitch pines at the intersection of Coopers Rd and Norlemon Rd
> The largest & oldest sporocarp had a cap of ~8 cm; younger mature sporocaps had ~5 cm caps
> The beautifully-colored deep red-violet cuticle peeled >3/4, almost to the center
> Gills white, crowded; some forking near the base and occasional forking elsewhere; lamellulae absent
> Spore print white
> Odor nil
> Taste mild
> Old 10% FeSO4 on stipe surface = negative
> Old 1.7% Guaiac Tincture on stipe surface = bluish-green in 5-10 sec.
> Keyed out to R. sericeonitens in Kibby/Fatto and Kibby’s online key at Russula News
results.location_name: Brendan T. Byrne State Forest, Burlington Co., New Jersey, USA

Qrange = 1.39-1.82
Qavg = 1.58
n=36
KOH on caps grayish brown.
UV light was negative for all parts.
results.location_name: Silver Fork Rd., Eldorado National Forest, El Dorado Co., California, USA

results.notes:
> A very large number (dozens) of fruiting bodies growing in large, gregarious clusters next to a trail near the Pakim Pond parking area.
> The vast majority of mushrooms were very small, with caps of ~1cm; the widest cap I saw was only 3.5 cm.
> Faint remnants of an arachnoid cortina seen on cap margin.
> The granules on cap and gills appear to be pine tree pollen (the pines are pollinating now as if there is no tomorrow).
> KOH stains the cap surface brown.

results.notes:
Colours of some of the detail photos are slightly too red/purple. The first photo and the collage show the colours the best.

Fourth or fifth observation of this species in the Netherlands. Here’s a map with the distribution of the previous observations:
https://www.verspreidingsatlas.nl/0024100

Description (translated from my original Dutch description):

Pileus:
20-40 mm, hygrophanous starting between the center and margin, very finely rugulose, when moist appearing granulose, when dry smooth to radially rugulose, young pruinose. Young dark brown sometimes with reddish hues, later brown, pale brown to leathery buff when entirely dry and old. When moist greasy to touch and shiny, when dry mat, dull (almost black brown). Margin weakly striate when moist, when dry undulating and ribbed at the outmost margin. Some specimens have a paler margin, whilst other specimens have a uniform colour.

Lamellae:
L: 36, l: 28. Slightly ventricose, adnexed, occasionally anasomose, subdistant, quite thin, darker toward the apex (dark brown). Paler margin (pale brown), margin smooth but irregular.

Stipe:
About the same size of the length of the width of the cap up to twice as long. On fresh specimens strikingly two to three toned, were the lower part is dark brown, changing into café au lait in the middle and pale at the apex. Entirely very finely velutinose. Hollow with loose hyphae. Tends to turn pale with very old specimens, though occasionally dark stiped specimens occur. Very pliable. Up to 5 mm broad at the apex, tapering towards the base, often compressed. White to pale brown rhizomorphs or rhizoids at the base.

Trama:
Thin, pale in the ap, darker towards the stipes foot.

Taste and smell:
Weak to rancid, pungent cabbage smell. Taste inconspicuous to rancid, slightly garlicy.

Habitat:
Botanical garden of my university, on coniferous woodchips from France (I asked the gardener), mesotrophic sandy soil. Other species growing within 20m: Amanita muscaria, Leccinum scabrum, Paxillus involutus sl, Russula/Lactarius sp (corpses), Collybia cirrhata and Laccaria laccata.

Growth form:
Gregariously, occasionally forming half a fairy ring, caepistose. Woodchips strikingly darker where the mushrooms are growing, probably due to water retaining.

results.notes:
Code: Bot_943/2016_DSC1208

Habitat: grassland, pasture, moderately southeast inclined mountain slope at the foot of a mountain; shallow, skeletal, calcareous soil; old overgrown colluvial ground; dry and sunny place, exposed to direct rain, average precipitations ~ 3.000 mm/year, average temperature 7-9 deg C, elevation 630 m (2.070 feet), alpine phytogeographical region.

Substratum: medium size Picea abies stump, in late disintegration stage.

Place: Lower Trenta valley, between villages Soča and Trenta, right bank of river Soča, ‘Na Melu’ place, East Julian Alps, Posočje, Slovenia EC.

Comments: Two sporocarps were found at the same place as the observation on March 11 (MO observation #235333), but on another Picea abies stump a few m from the first observation and in the same habitat. Both trees were cut down on the same day several years ago. In both cases the pilei appeared on the northeast side of the stumps. Pilei diameter 8.5 and 5.5 cm. The smaller pileus was left on the trump. It finally disintegrated around 3 May. This time the pilei were mature with asci containing spores. SP very faint, color undistinguishable.

Nikon D700/Nikkor Micro 105mm/f2.8
results.location_name: Lower Trenta Valley, East Julian Alps, Posočje, Slovenia

results.notes:
So I have solved the Rhodotus palmatus odor mystery! Field guides typically list it as having no odor. As it turns out, it’s actually the stinkiest mushroom I’ve ever come across, but only SOME people can smell it!
I had a sample and 20 willing, perhaps reluctant, participants. Of them, only myself and one little boy could smell it. It is a pungent, minty, chemically smell, reminiscent of camphor. (The little boy described it as peppermint.) It’s so strong I can smell it through a sealed ziplock baggie.

October, 2018 update:
Since then, I regularly poll people when they find it, and have had several smaller groups of people all sniff the same sample. Only about 1 out of 20 seem to be able to detect the odor.

results.notes: A solitary specimen fruiting in grass beside busy roadway in suburban area. Wet conditions from recent rain. My first impression when I looked at the gills was A. campestris, but closer inspection cast some doubts in my mind. Have not seen campestris with such a shaggy cap, nor one that so freely colored everything it touched pink. Rain droplets on gill surface were stained red (See 4th image); and gills were initially mottled (5th image). Also, over time the changes I observed were not the same as I have previously noted with A. campestris … even when wet. Cap: 10 cm.; stipe 5 cm. X 1.4 cm., essentially equal, slightly tapered at base, solid. Mild pleasant odor. KOH neg. on cap. The moisture in this specimen turned the paper plate I was using for a spore print instantly pinky-lilac, then a pinky-brown spore print developed in a few hours, and finally (overnight) a heavy very dark brown spore print developed. Wondering if this is just a very wet campestris, a variety of same, or a different species.

results.notes:
This is a non-usual one. When a took the photograph I thought to be a crustose one; Looking at the result I saw some membranaceous thallus ending by tiny lobes, all of dark grey-green colour with abundant soredia of the same colour but lighter; On the top of that: it is fertile, with black biatorine apothecia. I can’t figure what is its genus, even after micriscopy. Unfortunately, the photos are not so good, mainly because of the size and the colour, some being out of focus.

The microscopy reveals a section that seems to indicate the existence of a thalline rim envolving the apothecium, an algal layer with an alga that seems trentepohiloid with big orangish cells on the hypothecium; The asci are 8-spored and contains hyaline spores with 0 to 3 septa with the following dimensions:
(11.3) 12.5 – 17.4 (17.9) × (3.7) 3.74 – 4.7 (5.6) µm
Q = (2.7) 2.9 – 3.9 (4.1) ; N = 24
Me = 15.1 × 4.3 µm ; Qe = 3.5
The paraphyses are discrete having blackish tips, which gives such coloration to the epithecium in section.

results.notes:
Lichenicolous fungus growing on Pertusaria.

This is one more fungus that lives parasitic on a lichen, again a Pertusaria sp.. It seems that this lichen genus is one of the most vulnerable to parasitism, since many of my observations of lichenicolous fungus has a species in this genus as host or maybe the lichonicolous are best visble in their usually light coloured thallus.

The genus Skyttea was unknown to me before until very recently. My gratitude goes to Javier Etayo for first identifying the genus and then for suggesting S. pertusariicola as the species of the specimens found about one month ago. The specimens considered here are entirely similar to those found before.

The genus Skyttea is characterized by having dark-coloured apothecia with a pore-like opening, deeply urceolate when old, the exciple with one or several characteristic pigments, mostly of conglutinated hyphae with subglobose to ±cylindrical lumina, bordered near the margin by 0-1-septate hairs; non-amyloid asci apically strongly thickened, with a small ocular chamber.

S. pertusariicola was described for the first time in the Sonoran Flora, Vol. 2, and is one of the few species with a particular chemistry: K+ aeruginose green in the outer and central parts of the exciple and excipular hairs and K+ purplish violet in inner parts. All these features are well detailed in the attached photos. The main reference to the genus is the paper in Ref. 1, by P. Diedrich & J. Etayo, written before the description of the proposed species.

Braga, Portugal

results.notes:
Lichenicolous fungus growing on Pertusaria.

In observation 236813 (see the notes and comments therein) I considered a lichenicolous fungus (from a different location) to which I gave the name of the genus Minutoexcipula based on a suggestion of Javier Etayo, an expert on the subject, based on the photos of that observation. More recently I found at this place very similar material, of which I also send photos to J. Etayo. His opinion is that, only based on the photos, it is not possible to decide between the two genera Lichenodiplis and Minutoexcipula. The question seems to be connected of the margin of the ascomata and the existence and dimensions of the conidiophores. For the material of observation 236813 the conidiophores were long and septate whereas for this material they are inconspicious or inexistent. All my observations of these type of lichenicolous fingi have a common host: Pertusaria spp..

My gratitude to Javier Etayo for his help in relation to this material.

results.notes:
The identity of this bolete has not been firmly established, as it doesn’t quite look like the European I. badia or the North American version of this species found elsewhere in the Northeast and outside of the coastal plains.
This is not a common mushroom in the Pine Barrens. I know of only two sites where these grow. I’ve collected them before in May and in late October (e.g., obs 68166 and obs 56306), but they don’t make an appearance every year.
I plan to sequence this specimen.
> Two fruiting bodies growing in sandy soil on the border of a clearing in the woods. Pitch pines and blueberry bushes are the only plants nearby.
> The flesh is mild-tasting and the odor is pleasant.
> The context is faintly yellow in the cap, pinkish at the juncture of the cap and stipe and paler below (see pix); the cap context slowly stained pale blue (see pic).
> KOH (~3 y.o.) = deep reddish brown on cap surface & medium lemon yellow on cap context.
> NH4OH (~3. y.o.) = deep reddish brown on cap surface (blotted cap surface was rusty orange-brown) & pale yellow on cap flesh (erasing the bluing)
> FeSO4 (~3 y.o.) = pale olive on cap surface and greenish-yellow on cap context
DNA Sequencing Results & Discussion (last revised on 15-Jul-22):
> A clean full-length nrITS consensus sequence of two reads was obtained from this voucher by Dr. Kudzma. There are no ambiguities or heterogeneity; it’s a single haplotype. The sequence was deposited in GenBank.
> This sequence is 99.4-100% similar to accessions labeled as Imleria badia from North America (NA), as per the BLASTn results. In contrast to these, ITS sequences of I. badia from Europe have a face value similarity of 98-99% (for some reason this used to be one of the most commonly sequenced bolete, with hundreds of accessions from Europe). Why “face value” similarity? A MUSCLE alignment of the present sequence with a typical one from Europe is shown in Fig. 1. There is a curious 10-character deletion in the ITS2 region of the European sequence found in a few randomly sampled GenBank accessions from Europe and it is presumed to be the defining feature of the Old World genotype. Counting it in, the similarity drops from 98.83% to 96.85% (17 mismatching positions).
The ITS and TEF-1 sequences of I. badia from both sides of the Atlantic show a clear-cut phylogeographic pattern (see Fig. 2 & Fig. 3). This phenomenon is also observed in a couple of other boletes, e.g. Leccinum holopus.1 Published research on the phylogeny of Imleria doesn’t support elevation of the NA I. badia to a new species.2,3 Farid et al. (2020) write: “Based on ITS sequences, our results indicate that eastern North American I. badia form a weakly supported monophyletic clade distinct from a strongly supported clade of Eurasian sequences. These findings agree with those found by Zhu et al. (2014). This intraspecific divergence is likely due to geographic isolation (Zhu et al. 2014), and we are unaware of any reliable morphological differences.”
References:
1 Den Bakker et al., Phylogeographic patterns in Leccinum sect. Scabra and the status of the acrtic-alpine species L. rotundifoliae; Mycological Research 111: 663-672 (2007)
2 Farid et al., Expansion of the genus Imleria in North America to include Imleria floridana, sp. nov., and Imleria pallida, comb. nov.; Mycologia 112(2): 423-437 (2020)
3 Yang et al., The genus Imleria (Boletaceae) in East Asia; Phytotaxa 191(1): 081–098 (2014)

results.notes: As can be seen from the photo of the spot tests made in loco, there is a K+ yellow reaction and a darkning in KC; Some redish tones also appeared but seem to be at a place where the wood is visible. To get further insight I made thin sections of the thallus and analyzed under the microscope the reaction to KOH. The result is what I described above for the spot test and there no red reaction was observed. This is a point in favour of B. chloroleuca in relation to B. erubescens. Another point in favour of B. chloroleuca in relation to B. erubescens is the internal septation of young spores, since the mature ones are of Buellia-type in both species: tendency to Callispora-type in B. chloroleuca and Physconia-type in B. erubescens.

results.notes:
Area with several hemlocks in primarily hardwood forest.

Cap surface viscid (wet weather). Marginal striations faint but distinct.

Spores subglobose to globose with lengths 7-9 (or maybe just over 9).

Membranous material in soil near stipe appears to be from the volva. This patch was not attached to the stipe base. Most other A. praecox I have seen featured basal volval remnants (partially) attached to the stipe base, often as a margin encircling the upper stipe base. The stipe base was buried as seen in the photo, which may account for this. UV patch on the cap surface near the margin.

results.notes: Found on rotted hardwood. The caps are lubricious but not viscid, flatten at maturity, and fade evenly toward medium brown. Not hygrophanous. The margins are not notably pale. Gills crowded, whitish, narrowly attached. Stipes are smooth, clavate, and have copious white basal rhizomorphs. Spore print pale cream. Growth habit is cespitose. Resembles the description of G. brunneolus except for the substrate. Suggestions?
